item.title: Jordan accuses Prince Hamzah of plot to destabilise kingdom
item.description: The king's half-brother sought to mobilise tribal leaders against the government, the deputy PM says.

item.title: Kill the Bill protests: More than 100 arrested in London
item.description: More than 100 people are arrested after a demonstration against a bill to impose restrictions on protests.

item.title: Richard Okorogheye: Divers help search for missing student
item.description: Richard Okorogheye has not been seen by his family since he left his home on 22 March.

item.title: 2021 Boat Race: Cambridge beat Oxford in both men's and women's races
item.description: Cambridge win the 166th Boat Race in a contest moved to Cambridgeshire because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Covid: Passports showing vaccine status would be 'time-limited', says minister
item.description: The FA Cup Final will be among events to only admit fans who get a negative test or prove immunity.

item.title: Dorstone 'illegal rave': Police set up road blocks
item.description: The community is increasingly concerned about a "large gathering" in Dorstone, police say.

item.title: Florida declares state of emergency over toxic wastewater leak
item.description: More than 300 homes in the Tampa Bay area have been ordered to be evacuated.

item.title: Lucille Downer: Dogs 'humanely destroyed' after fatal attack in Rowley Regis
item.description: Lucille Downer, a great-grandma originally from Jamaica, died after a "sustained" attack, say police.

item.title: Newtownabbey: Man charged after police attacked and cars hijacked
item.description: Thirty petrol bombs were thrown at police and three cars hijacked and set alight on Saturday night.

item.title: Carabao Cup: Final between Tottenham & Man City to have 8,000 fans in stadium
item.description: The Carabao Cup final between Tottenham and Manchester City will have 8,000 fans in attendance after it is confirmed as a pilot event to test the return of big crowds.

item.title: Three charged after mass brawl at Edinburgh Meadows
item.description: Police said "thousands" had gathered at the Meadows in Edinburgh where violence erupted.

item.title: No BBQs plea after Peak District moorland fires
item.description: One blaze, which spread across three hectares, was caused by people cooking, fire crews say.

item.title: A55 Easter traffic brought to standstill as horse 'breaks down'
item.description: The equine brought the A55 in Gwynedd to a standstill when its vehicle broke down.

item.title: Marwa Elselehdar: 'I was blamed for blocking the Suez Canal'
item.description: Egypt's pioneering ship captain has been targeted over false rumours about her role in the incident.

item.title: WSL: Geese invade pitch at Brighton-Manchester United game
item.description: Several geese stop play at People's Pension Stadium during Brighton's 1-0 win over Manchester United.

item.title: London Zoo: Learning to be a zookeeper during lockdown
item.description: London Zoo apprentice Joe on how he is learning to be a zookeeper during the pandemic.

item.title: Long lost pen pals reunited after 70 years
item.description: Jim Johnston from Belfast tracked down his American pen pal seven decades after losing touch.

item.title: Egypt mummies: Parade transports remains of pharaohs
item.description: Amid fanfare, 18 kings and four queens were transported on custom-made vehicles designed to minimise vibration.

item.title: Project 17: Solving Singapore's food waste problem
item.description: Shan, 17, wants to find out just how much food gets wasted in his home country of Singapore.

item.title: Bakewell love locks removal plans leave families 'devastated'
item.description: Plans to remove hundreds of love locks from a Bakewell bridge leaves some families "gutted".

item.title: Hidden treasure: Hertford Union Canal gives up its secrets
item.description: Anna Borzello explores the Hertford Union Canal as it is drained for the first time in 20 years.

item.title: Wally the Walrus: Fears for safety as Tenby tourists get 'too close'
item.description: Conservationists urge Tenby tourists to enjoy the stray mammal's temporary visit "from a distance".

item.title: Bridgerton fans mourn Regé-Jean Page's exit
item.description: Kim Kardashian joins those lamenting the news about the second series of the popular Netflix show.

item.title: Egypt mummies pass through Cairo in ancient rulers' parade
item.description: The Cairo spectacle sees the remains of 18 kings and four queens taken to a new resting place.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Mozambique Palma attack: How people tried to flee the assault
item.description: Survivors and their family members recount what happened when Islamist militants targeted Palma.

item.title: China is 'trampling on Hong Kong's democracy'
item.description: With Beijing's influence now paramount, many in Hong Kong are torn between defiance and resignation.

item.title: England lockdown: Countdown to freedom
item.description: As coronavirus restrictions are lifted - when can you return to your favourite activities?

item.title: How Princess Diana has been portrayed on stage and in film
item.description: A new Broadway musical about the princess is just the latest in a series of portrayals of her life.

item.title: Covid-19: Three Essex survivors recount their experiences
item.description: Three people who survived coronavirus share their stories, from hospital to recovery.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: Late Willock goal earns Newcastle draw with Spurs
item.description: Newcastle earned a vital point in their fight for Premier League survival thanks to a late equaliser against Tottenham from on-loan Arsenal midfielder Joe Willock at St James' Park.

item.title: Rampant Sale hammer Scarlets to reach first Champions Cup quarter-final since 2006
item.description: Sale book a Heineken Champions Cup quarter-final trip to face La Rochelle with an emphatic 57-14 victory away to a woeful Scarlets side.

item.title: Martial could miss remainder of season, says Solskjaer
item.description: Manchester United forward Anthony Martial could miss the remainder of the season with an injury picked up on international duty, manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer says.

item.title: Real Sociedad manager Imanol Alguacil sings after Copa del Rey win
item.description: Real Sociedad manager Imanol Alguacil celebrates ending his side's 34-year wait for a major trophy after their Copa del Rey victory over Athletic Bilbao.

item.title: WSL: Chelsea 6-0 Birmingham City highlights - Sam Kerr scores first-half hat-trick as Chelsea thrash Birmingham
item.description: Watch highlights as Sam Kerr scores a first-half hat-trick as league leaders Chelsea secure a 6-0 victory against Birmingham City in the Women's Super League.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: How many cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Why is the EU unhappy with AstraZeneca?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms, pubs and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: Naga Munchetty: It’s time to talk about race
item.description: Naga Munchetty travelled across the UK to understand what race and racism means today.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
